title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Does Attendance Impact Team Performance in the MLB?
text:
There are rich teams and there are poor teams.
Then there’s 50 feet of crap.
And then, finally, there’s the Oakland Athletics.
Moneyball is one of my favorite movies, and one of the themes it explores is the key components to drawing fans to games, and how to keep them coming back for more. It’s been over twenty years since Billy Beane and his front office staff tried to dig their way out of the issues in Oakland and yet somehow, after all these years, the A’s still remain underneath that same 50 feet of crap.
If you want to make a case for the A’s you could argue that perhaps it’s the fact that their comically oversized coliseum sits in one of the largest metropolitan areas in the country, yet one that is home to two baseball teams, making it the lowest population supporting two teams. However, even if you split the entire Bay Area into two halves, you still end up with a larger market than Pittsburgh, Tampa and KC.
So, is there a connection between ballpark attendance and a team’s performance? Does a winning team draw larger crowds? Can a packed house fuel a successful season? To answer that, we’ll first need to explore how each team compares to the league average attendance, as well as each other.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(scales)
library(ggrepel)
attendance <- read_csv("attendance21-22.csv")
standings <- read_csv("mlbstandings2022.csv")
teaminfo <- read_csv("mlbteaminfo.csv")
combined <- attendance %>% inner_join(standings, by="Tm")

combinedinfo<- combined%>% inner_join(teaminfo, by="Tm")

OAK<- combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W < 70) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` < 800000)

MIA<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W < 70) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 907487)

LAD<- combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W > 105) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` > 3500000)

CLE <- combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W > 90) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` < 2000000)

TBR<- combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W > 84) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 1128127)

STL<- combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W > 92) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 3320551)

HOU<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W == 106) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` > 2000000)

NYY<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W == 99) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 3136207)

PHI<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W == 87) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 2276736)

PIT<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W == 62) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 1257458)

WSN<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W == 55) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 2026401)

twentytwoAtt<- attendance %>% 
  arrange(desc('2022 Att')) %>% 
  select(Tm, `2022 Att`)

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=attendance, aes(x=reorder(Tm, `2022 Att`), weight= `2022 Att`), fill = "light grey") +
  geom_bar(data=CLE, aes(x=reorder(Tm, `2022 Att`), weight= `2022 Att`), fill="#00385D") +
  geom_bar(data=HOU, aes(x=reorder(Tm, `2022 Att`), weight= `2022 Att`), fill="#EB6E1F") +
  geom_bar(data=PHI, aes(x=reorder(Tm, `2022 Att`), weight= `2022 Att`), fill="#E81828") +
  geom_text(aes(x=25, y=3390000, label="Houston won the world series"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=15, y=3050000, label="Philly made it to the world series"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=6, y=2500000, label="Cleveland won 92 games and finished 7th overall"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x="NYM", y=2890000, label="<<League Average Attendance"), color="blue") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 2151889, color="blue")+ 
  scale_y_continuous(labels=comma)+
  coord_flip()+
  labs(
    x="Team", 
    y="2022 Overall Attendance", 
    title="2022 MLB Average Attendance vs Individual Team Attendance", 
    subtitle="How MLB an teams 2022 season attendance compares to the league average.", 
    caption="Source: Baseball Reference | By Tenley Wright"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 17, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    axis.text.y=element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=14), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 





I wanted to explore the correlation between attendance and wins. It would appear that there are two opposite ends of the spectrum. On one hand, you have the aforementioned A’s, who in 2022 had the lowest attendance in the MLB and fittingly came dead last in the standings. On the other hand, you get the Los Angeles Dodgers, who had the highest attendance and (you guessed it) the most wins.
But what’s between those two extremes?
What’s interesting, is that between these two ends of the spectrum, there is little to no evidence of a correlation between wins and attendance. Sure, Houston had an above average attendance and even went on to win the World Series, but the Phillies were right there with them till the end with a middle of the road average attendance. Even further, Cleveland was sixth to last in Attendance, yet finished ranked 7th in 2022 with 92 wins.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=combined, aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W)) +
  geom_smooth(data=combined, aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), method="lm", se=FALSE)+
  scale_x_continuous(labels=comma)+
  geom_point(
    data=OAK, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#EFB21E") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=OAK, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=MIA, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#00A3E0") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=MIA, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=LAD, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#005A9C") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=LAD, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-20000, y=W+3, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=CLE, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#E50022") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=CLE, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W+.5, label=Tm))+
    geom_point(
    data=TBR, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#8FBCE6") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=TBR, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-800, y=W-2, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=STL, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#C41E3A") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=STL, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
   geom_point(
    data=HOU, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#EB6E1F") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=HOU, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`+409, y=W+1, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=PHI, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#E81828") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=PHI, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=WSN, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#AB0003") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=WSN, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W+2, label=Tm))+
labs(
    x="Attendance", 
    y="Wins", 
    title="The impact of Attendance on Performace in MLB", 
    subtitle="Attendance had little effect on a teams ability to win games.", 
    caption="Source: Baseball Reference | By Tenley Wright"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=15), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 





There are a number of factors that drive attendance at MLB ballparks. And the same is true for winning. I took my question one step further and tried to find a common theme between the teams that had high attendance and a high win percentage. Same for the teams on the low side of things. That common theme? Payroll.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=combinedinfo, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`), 
    color="#5c5c5c", 
    alpha=.3) + 
  scale_x_continuous(labels=comma)+
  scale_size_continuous(labels=comma)+
  geom_point(
  data=OAK, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`), 
    color= "#EFB21E",
     alpha=.3) +
  geom_text_repel(
  data=OAK, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=MIA, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`), 
    color= "#00A3E0",
    alpha=.3) +
  geom_text_repel(
  data=MIA, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=LAD, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`), 
    color= "#005A9C",
       alpha=.29) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=LAD, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-20000, y=W+3, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=CLE, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#E50022",
     alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=CLE, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W+.5, label=Tm))+
    geom_point(
    data=TBR, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#8FBCE6",
     alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=TBR, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-800, y=W-2, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=STL, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`), 
    color= "#C41E3A",
     alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=STL, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
   geom_point(
    data=HOU, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#EB6E1F",
     alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=HOU, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-5000, y=W+2, label=Tm))+
     geom_point(
    data=PHI, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#E81828",
    alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=PHI, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-50000, y=W+.5, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=PIT, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#FDB827",
    alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=PIT, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W-.5, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=WSN, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#AB0003",
    alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=WSN, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-50000, y=W+2, label=Tm))+
  labs(
    x="Season Attendance", 
    y="Wins", 
    title="The impact of Payroll on Attendance and Performance", 
    subtitle="In 2022, teams with a higher payroll were winning more games and drawing more fans to their ballpark.", 
    caption="Source: Baseball Reference | By Tenley Wright"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 19, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 14), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=11), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    legend.position="right"
    ) 





Billy Beane may have known how to find the best bargain deal on a shortstop, but when it comes down to it, the big bucks are winning on both sides of the fence.
It’s important to note, though, that correlation does not always equal causation. Just because there is a positive correlation between payroll and wins and attendance, it doesn’t necessarily mean that an increased payroll will automatically lead to more victories.

title: About Tenley Wright
text: Tenley is a sophomore at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, where she studies Sports Media and Communications with a minor in Art. When she’s not in class, she works for the Husker Athletics department as a Creative Media Intern. She has a passion for Action photography and graphic design and is working towards a future career in Sports media, hopefully working with the MLB, PGA or NCAA.

title: Tenley Wright's Blog
text:
library(tidyverse)

── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ──
✔ ggplot2 3.4.0      ✔ purrr   1.0.1 
✔ tibble  3.2.1      ✔ dplyr   1.0.10
✔ tidyr   1.2.1      ✔ stringr 1.5.0 
✔ readr   2.1.3      ✔ forcats 0.5.2 
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

library(scales)


Attaching package: 'scales'

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    discard

The following object is masked from 'package:readr':

    col_factor

library(ggrepel)
attendance <- read_csv("attendance21-22.csv")

Rows: 30 Columns: 10
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (1): Tm
dbl (9): Rk, 2021 G, 2021 Attendance, 2021 Attend/G, 2022 G, 2022 Att, 2022 ...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

standings <- read_csv("mlbstandings2022.csv")

Rows: 30 Columns: 29
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (19): Team, Strk, pythWL, vEast, vCent, vWest, Inter, Home, Road, ExInn,...
dbl (10): Rk, W, L, W-L%, R, RA, Rdiff, SOS, SRS, Luck

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

teaminfo <- read_csv("mlbteaminfo.csv")

Rows: 30 Columns: 17
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (4): Team, Succ%, Managers, Tm
dbl  (12): Attendance, Attend/G, BatAge, PAge, BPF, PPF, #HOF, #A-S, #a-tA-S...
time  (1): Time

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

combined <- attendance %>% inner_join(standings, by="Tm")

combinedinfo<- combined%>% inner_join(teaminfo, by="Tm")

Team data frames

OAK<- combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W < 70) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` < 800000)

MIA<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W < 70) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 907487)

LAD<- combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W > 105) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` > 3500000)

CLE <- combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W > 90) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` < 2000000)

TBR<- combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W > 84) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 1128127)

STL<- combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W > 92) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 3320551)

HOU<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W == 106) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` > 2000000)

NYY<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W == 99) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 3136207)

PHI<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W == 87) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 2276736)

PIT<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W == 62) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 1257458)

WSN<-combinedinfo %>% 
  filter(W == 55) %>% 
  filter(`2022 Att` == 2026401)

2022 attendance dataframe

twentytwoAtt<- attendance %>% 
  arrange(desc('2022 Att')) %>% 
  select(Tm, `2022 Att`)

bar/line chart

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=attendance, aes(x=reorder(Tm, `2022 Att`), weight= `2022 Att`), fill = "light grey") +
  geom_bar(data=CLE, aes(x=reorder(Tm, `2022 Att`), weight= `2022 Att`), fill="#00385D") +
  geom_bar(data=HOU, aes(x=reorder(Tm, `2022 Att`), weight= `2022 Att`), fill="#EB6E1F") +
  geom_bar(data=PHI, aes(x=reorder(Tm, `2022 Att`), weight= `2022 Att`), fill="#E81828") +
  geom_text(aes(x=25, y=3360000, label="Houston won the world series"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=15, y=3050000, label="Philly made it to the world series"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=6, y=2400000, label="Cleveland won 92 games and finished 7th overall"), color="black") +
  geom_text(aes(x=20, y=2850000, label="<<League Average Attendance"), color="blue") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 2151889, color="blue")+ 
  scale_y_continuous(labels=comma)+
  coord_flip()+
  labs(
    x="Team", 
    y="2022 Overall Attendance", 
    title="2022 MLB Average Attendance vs Individual Team Attendance", 
    subtitle="How MLB an teams 2022 season attendance compares to the league average.", 
    caption="Source: Baseball Reference | By Tenley Wright"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 17, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    axis.text.y=element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=14), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 




scatterplot

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=combined, aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W)) +
  geom_smooth(data=combined, aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), method="lm", se=FALSE)+
  scale_x_continuous(labels=comma)+
  geom_point(
    data=OAK, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#EFB21E") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=OAK, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=MIA, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#00A3E0") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=MIA, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=LAD, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#005A9C") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=LAD, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-20000, y=W+3, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=CLE, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#E50022") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=CLE, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W+.5, label=Tm))+
    geom_point(
    data=TBR, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#8FBCE6") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=TBR, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-800, y=W-2, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=STL, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#C41E3A") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=STL, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
   geom_point(
    data=HOU, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#EB6E1F") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=HOU, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`+409, y=W+1, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=PHI, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#E81828") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=PHI, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=WSN, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W), 
    color= "#AB0003") + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=WSN, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W+2, label=Tm))+
labs(
    x="Attendance", 
    y="Wins", 
    title="The impact of Attendance on Performace in MLB", 
    subtitle="Attendance had little effect on a teams ability to win games.", 
    caption="Source: Baseball Reference | By Tenley Wright"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=15), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'





bubble chart

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=combinedinfo, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`), 
    color="#5c5c5c", 
    alpha=.3) + 
  scale_x_continuous(labels=comma)+
  scale_size_continuous(labels=comma)+
  geom_point(
  data=OAK, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`), 
    color= "#EFB21E",
     alpha=.3) +
  geom_text_repel(
  data=OAK, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=MIA, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`), 
    color= "#00A3E0",
    alpha=.3) +
  geom_text_repel(
  data=MIA, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=LAD, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`), 
    color= "#005A9C",
       alpha=.29) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=LAD, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-20000, y=W+3, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=CLE, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#E50022",
     alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=CLE, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W+.5, label=Tm))+
    geom_point(
    data=TBR, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#8FBCE6",
     alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=TBR, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-800, y=W-2, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=STL, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`), 
    color= "#C41E3A",
     alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=STL, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, label=Tm))+
   geom_point(
    data=HOU, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#EB6E1F",
     alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=HOU, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-500, y=W+2, label=Tm))+
     geom_point(
    data=PHI, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#E81828",
    alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=PHI, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-50000, y=W+.5, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=PIT, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#FDB827",
    alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=PIT, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W-.5, label=Tm))+
  geom_point(
    data=WSN, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`, y=W, size= `Est. Payroll`),
    color= "#AB0003",
    alpha=.3) + 
  geom_text_repel(
  data=WSN, 
    aes(x=`2022 Att`-50000, y=W+2, label=Tm))+
  labs(
    x="Season Attendance", 
    y="Wins", 
    title="The impact of Payroll on Attendance and Performance", 
    subtitle="In 2022, teams with a higher payroll were winning more and drawing more fans to their games.", 
    caption="Source: Baseball Reference | By Tenley Wright"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 14), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot",
    legend.position="right"
    )
